projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

TOGETHER With the Articles for the rendring of it up, which were interchangably propounded and ≈øent on both ≈øides.
Authorized according to Order.
LONDON, Printed by M. O. for H. S. Iune, 24. 1644.

div.head: A LETTER from an Eminent Per≈øonage at the Leagure before Yorke, dated there the 16. of June. 1644.
div.p:
UPon Friday morning early the Marque≈ø≈øe New-ca≈øtle wrote to our Generals offering a Parley to begin that after-noone at three a clock, and to continue till eight at night, and a ce≈ø≈øation of Armes for three houres before, and three houres after to be held in Tent without the Wals, betwixt our Fort and theirs; with a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ i ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ ion of Guards, to ≈øuch number and di≈øtance as ≈øhould be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ≈øe and nece≈ø≈øarie: he named for Commi≈øsioners onely to treat ‚Ä¢ or him≈øelfe. The Lord Widrington, Sir Thomas Glemham, Sir
‚Ä¢ ichard Hutton, Sir William Wentworth, Sir Robert Strickland,
‚Ä¢ ir Thomas Me≈øham, and Ma≈øter Robert Rockley: Our Generalls accepted the offer in all poynts, and ≈øent for them; the Earle of
‚Ä¢ ind≈øey, the Lord Humby, Lieutenant Generall Baylie, Sir William Fairefax Colonell Hamond, Colonell Ru≈ø≈øell, and Colonell White: The≈øe fourteen met on Friday la≈øt, and the enemy propounded to our men certaine Articles which they brought in ‚Ä¢ n writing, but would not ≈øuffer our Commi≈øsioners to read nor other

coppy them. The Heads of them were ≈øuch as appeare in t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ other P ‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢ r therewith ≈øent. Our Commi≈ø≈øioners propound to them al≈øo certaine conditions, the true Coppy whereof I ≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ here al≈øo, offering a Coppy to the enemies to carry into York, be con≈øidered of, and after to return An≈øwer. The enemies Commi≈øsioners would not accept the Paper, but ≈øcornfully & prou ‚Ä¢
ly ≈øaid, They were below their condition, and much other pro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ language, which I c ‚Ä¢ nno ‚Ä¢ now write: ≈øo the Commi≈øsioners p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ted. But when Generall Le≈øley heard that the adver≈øaries Commi≈øioners refu≈øed to take the Paper containing the Conditions; h ‚Ä¢ pre≈øently clo≈øed the Paper in a Letter to the Marque≈ø≈øe Now ca≈øile, and ≈øent it by a Drum: Vnto which Letter and Pr ‚Ä¢ po≈øi ‚Ä¢
ons the Marq New ca≈øtle ye≈øterday after-noon returned an An≈øwer to this effect following. That our Generals pretending a de≈øire to prevent the effu≈øion of bloud, had framed and rendred t ‚Ä¢ him ≈øuch Conditions as neither he nor any man of Hono ‚Ä¢ with him could condi≈øcend unto any one of them: yet he would ≈øtill be teady to deliver up the Towne upon ≈øuch terme as he had offered him by his Commi≈øsioners the day before So you ≈øee the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe is now plainly left to be decided by th ‚Ä¢ Sword, of which the common Souldiers on out Party are nothing ≈øorry: The la≈øt night the enemy made fires on the to ‚Ä¢ of the Min≈øter, and Cliffords Tower, and were an≈øwered b ‚Ä¢ the like from Pomfret Ca≈øtle, which is a ≈øignall of ≈øuccours comming towards them: but I ≈øee no likelihood of any: fo ‚Ä¢ ye≈øterday and and this day al≈øo, we have Letters from Manche≈øter that Prince Rupert hath on Sa ‚Ä¢ urday and Friday la≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈øent part of his Army and Ordnance over the River Mer≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
into Che≈øhire, and hath lo≈øt one of his greate≈øt Pieces in the
pa≈ø≈øage of the Water: Some conjecture he intends to be≈øiege
‚Ä¢ arrington: others thinke he goes to ≈øuccour the King: If he ‚Ä¢ omes this way, our Armies are ready to encounter him.

After I had concluded this letter, word was brought mee that ‚Ä¢ he Earle of Manche≈øters men never acquainting our other Forces ‚Ä¢ ith their intention, ≈øptung a myne this afternoon, which d ‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢ ood execution, making a large breach in the wals into the man
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ , by which tho≈øe forces entred and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of ‚Ä¢ he Mannour, the enemies guards laying down their armes: But ‚Ä¢ he enemie drawing all their forces that way, beate out our men gaine, with the lo≈ø≈øe of 200. of our partee, and the other armies ‚Ä¢ ould not come to their ≈øuccour, having no notice of it.

div.head: The heads of their Propo≈øitions, as I heard them reported by our Commi≈ø≈øiioners at their return, made by the Marqe≈ø≈øe of Newca≈øtles Commi≈ø≈øioners, touching the Rendition of Yorke, Iune 14, 1644.

Fir≈øt, That him≈øelfe, with all the Commanders and ≈øouldiers, ≈øhould march away to the King with all their Ordnance, Armes, ammu

div.head: Propo≈øitions ≈øent from the three Generalls for the Parliament to the Treatie, June 14. 1644.
div.p: That the Citie of York with all the Forts, together with all arm ‚Ä¢ Ordnance, Ammunition, and other Warlike provi≈øions what≈øoever in and about the ≈øame, be rendred up to us, for the u≈øe of the Ki ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and Parliament.
Vpon the Conditions following, viz.

‚Ä¢ ir≈øt, That the Common Souldiers ≈øhall have free liberty and licence to depart and goe to their owne homes, and to carry ‚Ä¢ ith them their cloaths and their own moneyes, not exceeding „Äà‚óä„Äâ dayes pay, and ≈øhall have ≈øafe conduct & protection of their ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r≈øons from violence; They promi≈øing that they will not here
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ter take up Armes again≈øt the Parliament or Peote≈øtant Reli
‚Ä¢ ion.

2. That the Citizens and ordinary Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Citie, ≈øhall have their Per≈øons, goods, and Hou≈øes protected ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ om violence, and ≈øhall have the ≈øame free Trade and Comerce ‚Ä¢ s others under obedience of the King and Parliament, and that ‚Ä¢ o Regiments or Companies ≈øhall be admitted or quartered in ‚Ä¢ he Towne of Yorke, except tho≈øe that are appointed for the Gari≈øon thereof.

3. That the Officers of all qualities ≈øhall have liberty to goe to ‚Ä¢ heir own homes with Swords and Hor≈øes, and ≈øhall have ≈øafe ‚Ä¢ onduct to protection to that effect, and ≈øhall have licence to ca
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y their aparell and money along with them, the money not exceeding one mont≈øts pay for every ≈øeverall Officer.

4. That any Officer, who ≈øhall be recommended by the Marq: of Newca≈øtle, ≈øhall have a pa≈ø≈øe from any one of the Generalls to goe beyond the Seas, they promi≈øing not to ≈øerve again≈øt the Parliament and Prote≈øtant Religion.
5. That the Gentry and other Inhabitants of the County of Yorke ≈øhall have liberty to goe to their owne homes, and ≈øhall be protected from violence.

6. That a po≈øitive an≈øwer be returned to the≈øe Propo≈øiti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ by three of the clock to morrow in the Afternoone, being „Äà‚óä„Äâ 15. of this in≈øtant Iune: And in ca≈øe they ≈øhall not be then ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ted, we ≈øhall not then hold our ≈øelves bound to them; and in „Äà‚óä„Äâ meane time we declare that there is no Ce≈ø≈øation after 3. ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ already granted.
